author: nduijvelshoff
body:
When I try to setup a Remote PowerShell session from my MacOS to my Windows 10 IOT (ARM) via SSH (installed by default)  the response is: The SSH client session has ended with error message: subsystem request failed on channel 0.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Enter-PSSession -HostName <raspberry-ip> -UserName administrator
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
Getting in a remote PowerShell Core session such as from my MacOS  to Windows 10 (x64).
```powershell
Enter-PSSession -Hostname  <computer-ip> -UserName administrator
                                                                                                                                                                                   
[<computer-ip>]: PS C:\Users\Administrator\Documents>
```

Actual behavior
---------------
Getting an error on the local machine
```powershell
Enter-PSSession -HostName <raspberry-ip> -UserName administrator                                                                            
administrator@<raspberry-ip>'s password: 
Enter-PSSession : The background process reported an error with the following message: The SSH client session has ended with error message: subsystem request failed on channel 0.
At line:1 char:1
+ Enter-PSSession -HostName <raspberry-ip> -UserName administrator -SSHTra ...

+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.Management.Automation.Remoting.PSRemotingDataStructureException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.EnterPSSessionCommand
```

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
Just because SSH is installed does not mean it works out of the box. You also need to confgure it, have you done that on the client and host side? This includes configuring the subsytem and authentication.
See [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/tree/master/demos/SSHRemoting) for basic instructions to configure the subsystem. I have blogged [here](https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/heyscriptingguy/2017/12/29/cross-platform-powershell-remoting-in-action/) more details and examples that also include the configuration of authentication using RSA keys. For more details about other authentication methods of Win32OpenSSH, see their Wiki [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/Win32-OpenSSH/wiki) and for non-Windows devices, there is already plenty of documentation on authentication out there that you can search for.

comments.author: nduijvelshoff
comments.body:
Hi @bergmeister, just to make things clear, I have read all the documentation and can easily connect from my Mac to Windows Computer via PowerShell Core. I understand the need of configuring the Subsystem nut can't find any documentation for that (including your links).

Is there documentation to configure the Subsystem on a SSH Server running on Windows 10 IOT?

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
Ok, sounds like you already know what you are doing, therefore I assume in `sshd_config` on the Windows IOT you also have something similar to
````
Subsystem powershell C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0\pwsh.exe -sshs -NoLogo -NoProfile
RSAAuthentication yes
PubkeyAuthentication yes
PasswordAuthentication yes
````
Can you at least ssh to the Windows IOT box directly? This way one would know if it is a problem of `PowerShell` or `Win32-OpenSSH.`
You said that SSH is aready installed on the Windows IOT device. Could it be that it has not all features enabled? In the early days, 'installation' consisted of extracting the package and running some scripts to enable SSH server/agent features (i.e. the Windows Services `sshd` and `ssh-agent`). The documentation is still [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/Win32-OpenSSH/wiki/Install-Win32-OpenSSH). On Windows Server machines, I install it using chocolatet this way: `choco install -y openssh -params '"/SSHServerFeature /SSHAgentFeature"'`
This is as much as I can help you with. But keep in mind that ARM support of PowerShell is experimental at the moment and that `Win32-OpenSSH` is still in pre-release state.

comments.author: nduijvelshoff
comments.body:
@bergmeister the main issue for me is that I can't vind the SSH daemon (service) config on the Windows IOT, the SSH service it self is working (build-in), but until I can define the subsystem I'll have this issue I guess...

The configuration on Windows and Linux via sshd_config is working as expected, but have to find the configuration of Windows IOT.

comments.author: nduijvelshoff
comments.body:
The SSH service is running via "svchost.exe":

```cmd
  Proto  Local Address          Foreign Address        State
  TCP    0.0.0.0:22             RaspberryPI:0             LISTENING
 [svchost.exe]
```

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
There you go, you cannot expect ssh-remoting to work without configuring it first on the Windows IOT device. But even if it is built it, the `sshd_config` must still be somewhere, try searching for it. `svchost.exe` is the Windows daemon for Windows Services, this is expected since it runs as a Windows Service, you should see them by typing `Get-Service -Name "ssh*"`
But so far, it sounds to me that this issue rather belongs to the [Win32-OpenSSH](https://github.com/PowerShell/Win32-OpenSSH) repo. They might be able to tell you more about this built in version.

I have verified I can ssh to the machine directly (it gives me a standard - not power - shell) but fails within pwsh when running Enter-PSSession. I have tried the username with both username and DOMAIN\username syntax and get the same error.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: @treii28 Have you configured the PowerShell subsystem in the SSH client and server (in `ssh_config` config file)?
